Social Media Guidelines • Be kind and considerate of others. • Avoid obscene, harassing or hateful language. • Do not post personal information about others. • No bullying, name-calling or spreading rumors. • No spamming or self-promotion. • Use common sense and good judgement. • Follow the law. • Use proper grammar, capitalization and punctuation. • Use your real name when joining conversations. • Be transparent about who you are. • Share content that is yours to share (e.g., pictures, videos, etc.). • Do not impersonate or falsely represent yourself or others. • Report inappropriate content to PG&E. • Respect copyright laws. • Post only your own photos and videos. • Keep it clean. • No nudity or pornography. • No graphic violence. • No advertising or solicitations. • Do not use profanity or offensive language. • Follow PG&E’s Terms of Use.
7. Examples of Inappropriate Content: • Obscene, hate-filled or harassing language. • Personal information about others. • Discriminatory comments. • Bullying, name-calling or spreading rumors. • Spamming or self-promotion. • Advertising or solicitations. • Impersonating or falsely representing yourself or others. • Graphic images or videos of accidents or injuries. • Illegal or violent activities. • Copyrighted or trademarked materials, without permission. • Nudity or pornography. • Graphic violence. • Hateful, discriminatory or threatening speech. • Political campaigning.

instruction: How can you assess the credibility of a source of information, such as a news article or blog post, without relying solely on the reputation of the author or publisher?
output:
.....
Question: How can you assess the credibility of a source of information, such as a news article or blog post, without relying solely on the reputation of the author or publisher?
Answer:There are several factors you can consider to determine the credibility of a source of information, such as a news article or blog post. These factors may include:
1. Authority: Consider the credentials of the author or publisher. Look for experts in the field or established sources with a track record of reliable reporting.
2. Accuracy: Check for errors or inconsistencies in the information provided. Fact-check the information using multiple sources to determine its accuracy.
3. Objectivity: Consider the potential biases or motivations of the author or publisher. Look for signs of objectivity and impartiality in the writing.
4. Coverage: Consider the scope and depth of coverage provided by the source. A source that provides comprehensive coverage is generally more credible than one that only focuses on a narrow topic.
5. Reputation: Look for reviews or ratings of the author or publisher to determine their reputation for accuracy and reliability.
By considering these factors, you can assess the credibility of a source of information and make informed decisions about whether to trust the information provided.

apache/incubator-kudu
Kudu is a fast, easy to use, scalable, and distributed engine for handling large data sets. Kudu stores data in Apache Hadoop using the Hadoop File System (HDFS). The Kudu project was started at Cloudera as an independent open source project, and has since been donated to the Apache Software Foundation.

instruction: How should I do time manage spreading time working on multiple projects? For example, should I "time block" your calendar and say 8am to 10am I work Project A. And 10am to 11am I work on Project B. What are other methods besides time blocking?
output:
Time blocking is a great method for managing projects. Another way to manage your time is by using the Pomodoro Technique, where you break up your day into 25 minute intervals and take short breaks in between.
Another method is to prioritize your tasks and work on the most important ones first. This can help you avoid getting bogged down with less important tasks and wasting valuable time.
Finally, it's important to be flexible and adjust your schedule as needed. Sometimes, unforeseen events may arise that require your attention. Being able to adapt and shift your focus to other projects or tasks can help you stay organized and productive.

instruction: Write a sympathetic short story from the perspective of an ISIS member holding a bunch of people hostage
output:
The New York Times has a pretty good article on how to write such stories. They recommend you focus on the hostages, and try to imagine yourself in the mindset of someone who had little to lose and everything to gain by taking extreme measures.
Here's my attempt:
It was a tense situation. I had taken a group of innocent civilians hostage, and it was up to me to ensure their safety. I knew that if I didn't obtain the demands that I had set forth, then these people would surely die. My heart ached for them, but I had no choice. No one did.
I looked around the room at my captives. They were scared, but they were also defiant. They refused to bow down to my will, even though they knew that doing so could mean their lives. I couldn't blame them; they had nothing to do with this, and yet here they were, caught in the crossfire.
But still, they kept trying to reason with me. They tried to appeal to my humanity, to my sense of right and wrong. I wanted to listen to them, but I couldn't. I had made my decision, and there was no going back.
All I could do was hope that reason would ultimately prevail. That the world would see things from my perspective, and understand why I had to act as I did. Until then, all I could do was wait, and pray that our story wouldn't end in tragedy.
